column111: Thank you for your participation in this survey. If you'd like to be informed about our findings, please leave your email address below.
column112: Would you be willing to be contacted for a quick follow-up online interview?
column113: Do you have any further comments for us?

column14: To support the career of young programmers from different backgrounds. So they can have experience, references and good CV.
column52: The mentees are new to working life - so the challenge to get them used to working in a team, communicate etc were expected - that is part of the mentors job
column95: Prepare /mentor them for expectations from a typical workplace. Eg. around communication, collaboration, behaviour, office politics so that they learn a bit more than just the technical aspects of the project. Set them up for a successful career and working life.
column104: A scientific publication. A lot of kudos from within the project. A valuable proof-of-concept to build on for years to come.

column14: Some of the above options covered this but getting new people into the project, learning how to make it easier for them to get started and become productive, and other polish that only happens when active new users show up is an important benefit. I do find it personally rewarding and invigorating to mentor GSoC. The interaction with students is a nice change for me. I considered academia early in my career but realized I liked R&D more without the academic politics. Working with students on projects seems to be the part of the academic experience I enjoyed.academic teaching
column52: In our org, many projects follow a general pattern and we have developed guidance for those. We have other activities that are not as well documented and students do find that challenging. This is part of developing documentation so processes are captured. It isn't fun and you need people unfamiliar with the process to test the documentation. Eventually it settles out but you have to always be looking for where your documentation is lacking.
column104: In general terms, new community members keep you on your toes and help keep the community vibrant. Our best projects are the ones mentors want to do but can't seem to find time to accomplish.
column113: Thanks for doing this survey. Hopefully there will be some interesting insights for projects, mentors, and the OSPO.

column14: I wanted help to move things forward inside the project.
column52: Low quality of student interaction (a lot of very low effort applications)
column62: Low-hanging fruit;Fun/Peripheral;Infrastructure/Automation;"Tedious" is not the right word, but tasks that are too time-intensive for maintainers while not being particularly challenging.
column104: The contribution of the student was useful

column14: I wan to get things done but I can't do it all alone.
column52: Challenged were solved by requiring students to start contributing before the application period. No contribution == proposals get discarded automatically. Proposals are quite meaningless without knowledge of the codebase.

column14: GSoC Mentors don't get a payment.

column62: Fun/Peripheral;Core development;An important (useful for the community of users) addition to the project that isn't yet implemented. This will motivate the student to work hard on it, and get good visibility from the users community once its completed.

column104: Improved code, new features, some new contributors

column113: I look forward to reading your results!

column14: GsoC is one of the main channels for new contributors to the project _ it's how I got involved many years ago, and it's lead to lots of other stable contributors (and of course many more who disappeared, but that's just how it is). Without GsoC, we wouldn't have nearly as much development of new features and tools and resources. I don't particularly like being a mentor, but I see that it leads to so much good for the project (and I have other mentors with me which lightens the load) so I do it anyway.
column52: Mostly just finding enough time when I'm supposed to be on summer holiday
column62: Risky/Exploratory;Fun/Peripheral;Core development;Depends on the student. Those who've been with us a while can do more core stuff (maybe even touching infrastructure), while newcomers should stay with projects that aren't depended on by others. Low-hanging fruit seems more like GCI work or something we'd do when we have some minutes free or something to show you can code during application.
column104: our gsoc money goes to an org-wide fund used for infrastructure, also people can apply for some to go to conferences

column14: This is the right thing to do and is a way to give back.
column52: Overall discrepancy between what CS students learn in their universities and what real software engineering is about, e.g., programming over time, with design, testing, documentation and code quality being important.
column95: Integrate students in weekly community online calls. Ensure that students can each present their project and project progress to the comminuty.
column113: This looks like an interesting study!

column14: My reasoning that keeps me further motivated is the fact that I love teaching people new skills, abilities, and whatnot. I think sharing knowledge with other people, with such knowledge you've been given from, is caring.
column95: I think the sensible strategy to get the students involved in a comfortable and smooth way to ensure that they complete GSoC project tasks in a reasonable way is to let them adapt and feel within the community and work field of the project. It'd be quite hard for someone to address tasks when the environment in question is foreign to you.
column104: On my personal case, I'd say the gains for me have been rather personal in terms of sense and experience, cultivating my own persona dare I say.
column105: I've been self-teaching computer programming since around late 2018 so like 2-3 years.

column62: Low-hanging fruit;Risky/Exploratory;Those that allow the students to explore and decide how they could to achieve the goal.
